Using this card, generally speaking, would you say that most people can be trusted, or that you can't be too careful in dealing with people?
Please tell me on a score of 0 to 10, where 0 means you can't be too careful and 10 means that most people can be trusted.

Most people would try to take advantage of me

Now we want to ask you a few questions about politics and government

0 means you do not trust the institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust.
Some people don't vote nowadays for one reason or another.
Did you vote in the last British general election in May 2010?
Which party did you vote for in that election?
There are different ways of trying to improve things in Britain or help prevent things from going wrong.

Do you feel that you are

In politics people sometimes talk of “left” and “right”.
Using this card, where would you place yourself on this scale, where 0 means the left and 10 means the right?
All things considered, how satisfied are you with your life as a whole nowadays?
Please answer using this card, where 0 means extremely dissatisfied and 10 means extremely satisfied.
On the whole how satisfied are you with the present state of the economy in Britain?
Now thinking about the government of the UK, how satisfied are you with the way it is doing its job?
And on the whole, how satisfied are you with the way democracy works in Britain?
Now, using this card, please say what you think overall about the state of education in Britain nowadays?
Still using this card, please say what you think overall about the state of health services in Britain nowadays?
Using this card, please say to what extent you agree or disagree with each of the following statements.
The government should take measures to reduce differences in income levels.
Gay men and lesbians should be free to live their own life as they wish.
Political parties that wish to overthrow democracy should be banned.
Modern science can be relied on to solve our environmental problems.
Now some questions about people from other countries coming to live in Britain.
Now, using this card, to what extent do you think Britain should allow people of the same race or ethnic group as most of Britain's people to come and live here?
Allow many to come and live here
How about people of a different race or ethnic group from most British people?
Allow many to come and live here
How about people from the poorer countries outside Europe?
Allow many to come and live here
Would you say it is generally bad or good for Britain's economy that people come to live here from other countries?
And, using this card, would you say that Britain's cultural life is generally undermined or enriched by people coming to live here from other countries?
Is Britain made a worse or a better place to live by people coming to live here from other countries?
And now a few questions about you and your life.
Taking all things together, how happy would you say you are?
Using this card, how often do you meet socially with friends, relatives or work colleagues?
Do you have anyone with whom you can discuss intimate and personal matters?
Compared to other people of your age, how often would you say you take part in social activities?
Have you or a member of your household been the victim of a burglary or assault in the last 5 years?
How safe do you – or would you - feel walking alone in this area after dark?
How often, if at all, do you worry about your home being burgled?
Please choose your answer from this card.
All or most of the time

erious effect on the quality of your life,
or no real effect on the quality of your life?

...made an exaggerated or false insurance claim?
...bought something you thought might be stolen?
..committed a traffic offence like speeding or crossing a red light?
Now some questions about the police in ENGLAND.
Taking into account all the things the police are expected to do, would you say they are doing a good job or a bad job?
Choose your answer from this card.
In the past 2 years, did the police in ENGLAND approach you, stop you or make contact with you for any reason?
How dissatisfied or satisfied were you with time this happened?
Choose your answer from this card.
Now some questions about whether or not the police in ENGLAND treat victims of crime equally.
Please answer based on what you have heard or your own experience.
When victims report crimes, do you think the police treat rich people worse, poor people worse, or are rich and poor treated equally?
Choose your answer from this card.
And when victims report crimes, do you think the police treat some people worse because of their race or ethnic group or is everyone treated equally?
Choose your answer from this card.
People from a different race or ethnic group than most English people treated worse
People from the same race or ethnic group as most English people treated worse
Everyone treated equally regardless of their race or ethnic group
Based on what you have heard or your own experience how successful do you think the police are at preventing crimes in ENGLAND where violence is used or threatened?
Choose your answer from this card, where 0 is extremely unsuccessful and 10 is extremely successful.
And how successful do you think the police are at catching people who commit house burglaries in ENGLAND?
If a violent crime were to occur near to where you live and the police were called, how slowly or quickly do you think they would arrive at the scene?
Choose your answer from this card, where 0 is extremely slowly and 10 is extremely quickly.
Now some questions about when the police deal with crimes like house burglary and physical assault.
The next few questions do not have a showcard.
Based on what you have heard or your own experience how often would you say the police generally treat people in ENGLAND with respect
About how often would you say that the police make fair, impartial decisions in the cases they deal with?
And when dealing with people in ENGLAND, how often would you say the police generally explain their decisions and actions when asked to do so?
(No one ever asks the Gardaí to explain their decisions and actions)
Now some questions about your duty towards the police in ENGLAND.
Use this card where 0 is not at all your duty and 10 is completely your duty.
To what extent is it your duty to
back the decisions made by the police even when you disagree with them?
do what the police tell you even if you don't understand or agree with the reasons?
do what the police tell you to do, even if you don't like how they treat you?
Using this card, please say to what extent you agree or disagree with each of the following statements about the police in ENGLAND?
The police generally have the same sense of right and wrong as I do.
The police stand up for values that are important to people like me.
I generally support how the police usually act.
The decisions and actions of the police are unduly influenced by pressure from political parties and politicians.
Now one last question about the police and things they may or may not do.
How often would you say that the police in ENGLAND take bribes?
Choose your answer from this card where 0 is never and 10 is always.
I am now going to ask you some questions about the courts in ENGLAND that deal with crimes such as house burglary and physical assault.
Again please answer based on what you have heard or your own experience.
Taking into account all the things the courts are expected to do, would you say they are doing a good job or a bad job?
Choose your answer from this card.

Use this card where 0 is never and 10 is always.
How often do you think the courts make fair, impartial decisions based on the evidence made available to them?
Now some questions about the chances of different people in ENGLAND being found guilty of crimes they did not commit.
Suppose two people - one rich, one poor - each appear in court, charged with an identical crime they did not commit.
Choose an answer from this card to show who you think would be more likely to be found guilty.
The rich person is more likely to be found guilty
The poor person is more likely to be found guilty
They both have the same chance of being found guilty
Now suppose two people from different race or ethnic groups each appear in court, charged with an identical crime they did not commit.
Choose an answer from this card to show who you think would be more likely to be found guilty.
The person from a different race or ethnic group than most English people is more likely to be found guilty
The person from the same race or ethnic group as most English people is more likely to be found guilty
They both have the same chance of being found guilty

Courts generally protect the interests of the rich and powerful above those of ordinary people.
People who break the law should be given much harsher sentences than they are these days.
Everyone has a duty to back the final verdict of the courts.
All laws should be strictly obeyed.
Doing the right thing sometimes means breaking the law.
The decisions and actions of the courts are unduly influenced by pressure from political parties and politicians.
